questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the pathophysiology of Kartagener's syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutation in the CFTR gene leading to impaired ciliary function.

options.label: B
options.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern affecting the cilia in the respiratory tract.

options.label: C
options.text: The primary defect involves dynein arm proteins, leading to impaired ciliary motility.

options.label: D
options.text: Characterized by an excess of cilia in the respiratory epithelium.

questions.correct_answer: C. The primary defect involves dynein arm proteins, leading to impaired ciliary motility.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about mesothelioma?

options.label: A
options.text: Most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure

questions.correct_answer: C. Leads to a mediastinal shift
questions.explanation:
Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer (Option A)
  • It is not associated with smoking (Option D)

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene- CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion) (Options C and D)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin.
    • Epithelial membrane antigen.
    • Cytokeratin.
    • Mesothelin.

Prognosis
  • Poor (median survival of 9-21 months).

 

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

  

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain
   

Lobulated pleural soft tissue mass encasing the right lung. Associated erosion of the right 3rd rib anteriorly.

Calcified pleural plaques were noted bilaterally, indicating previous asbestos exposure.

Mesothelioma - sarcomatoid. Case study, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 06 Dec 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-8705" data-hash="" data-license="NA" data-source="https://radiopaedia.org/cases/mesothelioma-sarcomatoid#image-317742" data-tags="" height="412" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/Lb5Yo2BxBeec0AAu0gGy1737532157.png" width="500" />Coarse, partially calcified right pleural plaques, accompanied by massive right pleural effusion, causing total right lung collapse and mass effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an IHC marker for small-cell lung carcinoma?

Match the following occupational lung diseases with their characteristics. A) Byssinosis 1. Iron exposure B) Bagassosis 2. Monday disease C) Siderosis 3. Non-caseating granuloma. D) Berylliosis 4. Sugarcane dust exposure
questions.explanation:
A. Byssinosis

2. Monday disease

B. Bagassosis

4. Sugarcane dust exposure

C. Siderosis

1. Iron exposure

D. Berylliosis

3. Non-caseating granuloma.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of asbestos is more toxic?
questions.explanation:
Serpentine/ Chrysolite

Amphibole/ Crocidolite/ Amosite

Wavy

Rigid

More common (90% of the asbestos)

More pathogenic (amphiboles particularly associated with mesothelioma)

Mnemonic:

  • I am crying (Chrysotile)
  • After looking at a snake (Serpentine)
  • Snake is wavy
  • Snakes can be seen more commonly (more common)

Mnemonic:

  • I am on a site (Amosite)
  • Saw a Crocodile (Crocidolite)
  • Which is an Amphibian
  • Crocodile is straight (rigid)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of eggshell calcification?

In a histopathological examination of a lung biopsy from a patient with suspected sarcoidosis, which of the following microscopic features would be most characteristic and supportive of the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment

options.label: B
options.text: Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

questions.text: Which immunologic abnormalities are observed in the local milieu of sarcoid granulomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Accumulation of CD8+ T cells and increased CD8/CD4 T-cell ratio

options.label: C
options.text: Increased levels of Th1 cytokines such as IL-4 and IL-10

options.label: D
options.text: Accumulation of CD4+ T cells and increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios

questions.correct_answer: D. Accumulation of CD4+ T cells and increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratios

questions.text: A 55-year-old former shipyard worker presents with progressive dyspnea and left-sided chest pain for three months. He has a history of occupational asbestos exposure. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Imaging shows left-sided pleural thickening and effusion. Biopsy confirms mesothelioma. Which of the following statements is not accurate about mesothelioma and adenocarcinoma following asbesto exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: Adenocarcinoma often has a shorter latency period compared to mesothelioma following asbestos exposure.

options.label: B
options.text: Mesothelioma under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli.

options.label: C
options.text: Mesothelioma often presents with positive staining for calretinin and WT-1.

options.label: D
options.text: Adenocarcinoma is commonly associated with EGFR mutation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mesothelioma under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Malignant mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma lung

Origin

Arises from mesothelial cells lining the pleura.

Arises from glandular epithelial cells.

Association with asbestos exposure

Most specific tumours due to asbestos exposure

M/C carcinoma in asbestos exposure.

Latency period

25-45 years after asbestos exposure

10-30 years after asbestos exposure (Option A)

Specific genetic mutations

NF2, BAP1, chromosome 9p deletion

EGFR, ALK, KRAS (Option D)

Pathological features

Epithelioid, sarcomatoid, or biphasic patterns

Various growth patterns, glandular differentiation

Immunohistochemistry

Keratin, Calretinin, WT-1 (Option C), cytokeratin 5/6, podoplanin

Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1)

Electron microscopy

Long, slender, branching microvilli (Option B)

Short and non-branching microvilli

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with pleuritic chest pain and a pleural-based mass observed on imaging studies. Histopathological examination of a biopsy from the mass reveals spindle-shaped cells within a collagenous stroma. Which immunohistochemical marker would be most useful in differentiating solitary fibrous tumour (SFT) from mesothelioma?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Solitary Fibrous Tumor (SFT)

Malignant Mesothelioma

Nature of the tumour

Mostly benign, rare malignant

Malignant

Histopathology

Dense fibrous tissue, spindle cells, occasional cysts

Diffuse, invasive tumour growth across the pleural surface

Immunohistochemistry
  • Positive for CD34 and STAT6.
  • Negative for Keratin.
  • Positive for Calretinin, WT1, cytokeratin 5/6, and podoplanin.

Morphology

Tumours, often pedunculated and attached to the pleural surface, may have a whorled appearance.


 

Thick, firm, gelatinous tissue ensheathing the lung; often extensive effusion.

Microscopic appearance

Spindle cells are arranged in whorls among reticulin and collagen fibres.

Variable: Epithelioid (tubular/papillary structures), sarcomatoid (fibrosarcoma-like), or biphasic

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in?
Which of the following is not true regarding chronic bronchitis?

options.label: B
options.text: The most common cause is smoking

options.label: C
options.text: The most common cause of exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae.

options.label: D
options.text: Recurrent, episodic attacks of wheezing, prolonged expiration, dyspnea (shortness of breath), and chest tightness.

questions.correct_answer: D. Recurrent, episodic attacks of wheezing, prolonged expiration, dyspnea (shortness of breath), and chest tightness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the pathogenesis sequence of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is incorrect? Endothelial activation is the hallmark of pathogenesis. Release of cytokines by alveolar epithelial cells Macrophage activation resulting in the release of IL-8 and TNF Recruitment of lymphocytes by IL-8
Which of the following mechanisms is not involved in the development of emphysema?

options.label: A
options.text: Toxic injury and inflammation leading to variable degrees of parenchymal destruction.

options.label: B
options.text: Protease-antiprotease imbalance with a relative deficiency of protective antiproteases.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of T and B cells in affected parts of the lung indicates a robust adaptive immune response.

options.label: D
options.text: Oxidative stress induced by substances in tobacco smoke, alveolar damage, and inflammatory cells.

questions.correct_answer: C. The presence of T and B cells in affected parts of the lung indicates a robust adaptive immune response.

questions.text: Match the following types of emphysema with their characteristic features: Types of Emphysema Characteristic Features 1) Centriacinar emphysema A) Uniformly affects the entire acinus, commonly associated with alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency 2) Panacinar emphysema B) Predominantly involves the upper lobes, often associated with bullae formation. Alveolar ducts and sacs are spared 3) Paraseptal emphysema C) Associated with scarring and fibrosis, often seen in patients with chronic inflammation or recurrent infections 4) Irregular emphysema D) Involves the distal airways and is often associated with spontaneous pneumothorax
questions.explanation:
Features

Centriacinar (M/C)

Panacinar

Paraseptal

Irregular

Involves

Proximal acinus

Proximal & distal acini

Distal acinus

Irregular involvement

Site

Upper lobes especially apical segments

Lower zones & anterior margins of the lung.

 

More severe at the base of the lung.

The upper half of the lungs (more severe).

 

Airspaces can form cyst-like structures.

Any part of the lung can be involved.

Aetiology

Smokers

 

Chronic bronchitis

α1-antitrypsin deficiency

Spontaneous pneumothorax

Depends on involvement, most found in autopsy

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with cough and breathing difficulty and was diagnosed with emphysema after radiographic examination. Which of the following genetic conditions should be suspected as a possible cause?

Match the following lesions with their site of occurrence. Lesion Site 1 Puhl’s focus i Lung + Lymph node 2 Simon focus ii Blood vessels 3 Ghon complex iii Supraclavicular region of the lung 4 Weighert focus iv The apex of the lung
questions.explanation:
Puhl’s focus

Supraclavicular region of the lung

Simon focus

Apex of the lung

Ghon complex

Lung + Lymph node

Weighert focus

Blood vessel

Primary tuberculosis
  • It develops in a previously unexposed and therefore unsensitized person.
  • The primary organ involved is mostly the lungs.
  • Location:
    • Sub-pleural region.
    • Lower part of the upper lobe & upper part of the lower lobe.
  • Ghon’s focus: Grey-white area of inflammation with consolidation.
  • Ghon’s complex: Ghon’s focus + inflamed regional lymph nodes (Statment iii).
  • Histology: Granulomatous inflammatory reaction with both caseating and non-caseating tubercles.
  • Simon’s focus: Occult hematogenous dissemination to the apex of the lung. (Statement ii)
  • Fate:
    • 95% of the cases are controlled by immunity, calcified, healed lesions and hilar lymph nodes (Ranke complex).
    • 5% of the cases are progressive (Progressive primary TB).
      • Resembles acute bacterial pneumonia.
      • Lymphohematogenous dissemination may cause tuberculous meningitis and/or miliary TB.

Secondary tuberculosis
  • It arises in a previously sensitised host.
  • It may follow shortly after primary tuberculosis, but more commonly, it appears months to years after the initial infection, usually when the host resistance is weakened.
  • The apical and posterior lobe segments are involved due to high O2 concentration (Puhl’s focus) (Statement i).
  • The infraclavicular lesion is called Assman’s focus.
  • Regional lymph node involvement is late.
  • Cavitation occurs readily with the erosion of the cavities into an airway.
  • Histology: Active lesions show coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Caseous necrosis).

Disseminated TB: Spread to other organs.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with aspiration?
Red hepatisation of the lungs is seen on which day?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Days

Characteristics

Congestion

1-2

(Option A)
  • Gross: The lung is heavy, boggy, and red.
  • Microscopic: Vascular engorgement, intra-alveolar fluid with neutrophils & bacteria.

Red hepatization

2-4 (Option B)
  • Gross: Red, firm, and airless, with a liver-like consistency, hence the term hepatization.
  • Microscopic: Confluent exudation with neutrophils, RBCs, and fibrin filling the alveoli.

Grey hepatization

5-8

(Option C)
  • Gross: Greyish brown and dry surface.
  • Microscopic: Disintegration of RBCs and persistence of a fibrinosuppurative exudate.

Resolution

8-9

(Option D)
  • Exudates within the alveoli are broken down by enzymatic digestion to produce granular debris.
  • Debris may be reabsorbed/ingested by macrophages/expectorated/organised by fibroblasts.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding extralobular sequestration?

options.label: A
options.text: It is external to the lung.

options.label: B
options.text: It most commonly presents as a mass lesion.

options.label: C
options.text: It most often occurs in older children.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a separate pleural covering.

questions.correct_answer: C. It most often occurs in older children.
questions.explanation:
Extralobar sequestration

Intralobar sequestration

Location

External to the lung parenchyma

(Option A)

Within the lung parenchyma

Pleural covering

It has a separate pleural covering

(Option D)

Shares pleura with adjacent lung tissue

Embryological origin

Congenital anomaly of the primitive foregut

Association

It causes a mass effect

(Option B)

Localized infection or bronchiectasis

Venous return

The right side of the heart through IVC

Pulmonary veins
